title-group.article-title: On the taxonomy of the Zodarion thoni species-group (Araneae, Zodariidae), with description of a new species with an unmodified embolus

sec.title: N/A
sec.p:
On the taxonomy of the
Zodarion thoni
species-group ( Araneae , Zodariidae ), with description of a new species with an unmodified embolus
National Museum of Natural History, Bulgarian Academy of Sciences, 1 Tsar Osvoboditel Blvd., 1000 Sofia , Bulgaria

sec.title: Abstract
sec.p:
A new species of
Zodarion
, belonging to
Z. thoni
-group, is described from the Taurus Mountains, Turkey . By now, it is the only known species with an unmodified embolic tip in this group. The syntypes of
Z. rhodiense Caporiacco, 1948
,
Z. nigrifemur Caporiacco, 1948
, and the holotype of
Z. granulatum Kulczyński, 1908
are revised.
Zodarion rhodiense
sp. reval. is revalidated and
Z. nigrifemur
syn. n.
is assigned as its junior synonym.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p:
The genus
Zodarion Walckenaer, 1826
comprises 169 valid species, partially split into species groups. The focus of the present study is the
Z. thoni
group, which distribution is restricted to the Eastern Mediterranean, Caucasus and the Balkans. The group currently consists of six species:
Z. thoni Nosek, 1905
,
Z. granulatum
,
Z. reticulatum
,
Z. nigrifemur Caporiacco, 1948
,
Z. beroni Komnenov & Chatzaki, 2016
, and
Z. imroz Dimitrov, 2020
.
described
Zodarionthoni
from Anatolia , Turkey .
described
Zodarion granulatum
,
Zodarion reticulatum
and
Zodarion thoni cypria
. The latter was elevated to a full species level by
.
questioned the identity of
Z. cyprium
and considered it to be conspecific with
Z. thoni
, without synonymizing them explicitly. This opinion was not followed by
and
, who considered
Z. cyprium
a separate species.
described
Zodarion rhodiense
with two subspecies—the nominate
Z. rhodiense rhodiense
and
Z. rhodiense nigrifemur
. Brignoli (1984) re-described the nominate subspecies and elevated it to full species—
Z. rhodiense
.
synonymized
Z. rhodiense
with
Z. granulatum
and elevated
Z. rhodiense nigrifemur
to full species. In the same paper, he diagnosed the
Z. thoni
-group and summarized its complex history.
described
Zodarion parashi
, which was subsequently synonymized with
Z. granulatum
by
. All of the species in this group have modified tip of the embolus, which was used by
to diagnose the group.

While studying this group I recognized one undescribed species from Turkey with an unmodified tip of the embolus, kept in the collection of the Museum of Natural History Vienna. It is described in the present paper. Examining its closest relatives revealed another problem in the taxonomy of the group, concerning
Z. rhodiense
and
Z. nigrifemur
. After studying the syntypes of the two species, as well as the holotype of
Z. granulatum
Idiscovered that
Z. rhodiense
and
Z. nigrifemur
were conspecific, but different from
Z. granulatum
. Hence, the synonymy of
Z. rhodiense
with
Z. granulatum
proposed by
was not correct. Therefore, Itake the occasion to remove its synonymy, to revalidate the species
Z. rhodiense Caporiacco, 1948
, and consider
Z. nigrifemur Caporiacco, 1948
as its junior synonym.

sec.title: Material & methods
sec.p: The material is preserved in 75% ethanol. The specimens were examined using a Zeiss Stemi 508 stereomicroscope. The palps were dissected to be studied, photographed, and illustrated. The photographs of the palp were taken with Canon EOS 1100D, attached to a Carl Zeiss Amplival compound microscope. The body was photographed with the same camera, attached to a Zeiss compound microscope. The images were stacked using Helicon Focus stacking software and then processed in Photoshop. The drawings were made with Wacom tablet and Adobe Illustrator software. The color is described from a specimen, kept for a long time in ethanol. All measurements are in mm. The leg measurements formula: total length (coxa + trochanter, femur, patella, tibia, metatarsus, tarsus).

Abbreviations: Morphology. ALE—anterior lateral eyes; AME —anterior median eyes; C—conductor; E— embolus; PLE—posterior lateral eyes; MA—median apophysis; PME—posterior median eyes; RTA—retrolateral tibial apophysis. Institutions. MZUF —Museum of Natural History, La Specola, Florence, Italy ; MZV—Museum and Institute of Zoology, Warsaw, Poland ; NMW —Museum of Natural History, Vienna , Austria .

Remarks. The type series is sufficiently small, and the diagnostic characters remain stable (see
). Consequently, the designation of a Lectotype (and Paralectotypes ) seems unnecessary, as it does not confer any discernible nomenclatural advantages (See Article 74.7.3 of the International Code of Zoological Nomenclature (1999)) .

Diagnosis (partial, male).
Zodarion rhodiense
sp. reval. belongs to
Z. thoni
species-group, judging from its large rectangular median apophysis and long, arch-shaped embolus (
). It is morphologically most close to
Z. thoni
because of its very similar lanceolate tip of the embolus, with a specific knob on the prolateral side. The only difference between the two is that in
Z. rhodiense
sp. reval. the embolic tip is thinner, longer, and twisted backward (
), while in
Z. thoni
it is wider and shorter ( Bosmans 2009 : figs 168–169; Lecigne & Henrard 2022 : fig. 5B–C).

Colouration (
). Carapace brown with dark brown pattern. The fovea is well-visible, dark brown. Legs with dark brown femora, as dark as the carapace pattern. The other leg segments yellowish. Sternum yellowish with light brown pattern. Chelicerae the same color as the carapace. The palpal femora brown, the other segments yellowish to light brown. Dorsal abdominal scutum black, with a metallic glint, without a pattern. Abdomen almost black, but lighter than the scutum. There is a small white spot above the spinnerets, another (bigger) one ventrally, and a broad diagonal white stripe on each side. The lateral and abdominal white areas connected. Colulus well visible, yellowish, with brown rim. Spinnerets yellowish with light-brown pattern in the base. AME significantly larger than the other eyes. Chelicerae with opistognathic position. Femoral organ with 3 setae on femur I [Since the material is in very bad condition, it was not possible to examined them on the other legs, but see Lecigne & Henrard, 2022: 36 , fig. 3A–D]. Abdomen with 2 spinnerets and narrow dorsal scutum, not covering its whole length. Colulus shaped as a broad, hairy plate.
Variations of the body size (based on the adult syntypes only). Carapace 1.80–2.08; abdomen 1.80–2.02.

Remarks. When synonymizing
Z. rhodiense
with
Z. granulatum , Bosmans (2009)
referred to the description and drawings of
Z. rhodiense
providedby Brignoli (1984: figs 50–53). They indeed correspond to
Z. granulatum
, but this is due to misidentification. Brignoli (1984) has described and depicted
Z. granulatum
instead of
Z. rhodiense
. I was able to find and examine the syntypes of the two subspecies
Z. rhodiense rhodiense
and
Z. rhodiense nigrifemur
. Males have fully identical tips of the embolus (
) and no other somatic or genital differences. Even the main diagnostic feature (the color of the femur) is identical between the two (
). However, the tip of the embolus clearly differs from those of
Z. granulatum
(
). The females collected with both
Z. r. rhodiense
and
Z. r. nigrifemur
were not conspecific with the males and belong to
Zodarion frenatum
(
). I include also photographs of
Z. frenatum
from Bulgaria for comparison (
). Ido not update the female diagnosis because there were no females belonging to
Z. rhodiense
sp. reval. among the syntypes . Since Caporiacco (1948) named the species
Z. rhodiense
in the original description, this name has priority and is revalidated, whereas its subspecies
Z. r. nigrifemur
n. syn.
is assigned as a junior synonym to the nominate one.

Type material.

05.06.1964
( NMW )
.

Etymology .
Named after the Namrun castle, the type locality of the species; noun in apposition.

Diagnosis. The species belongs to
Z. thoni
group (sensu Bosmans 2009 ), judging from the large, rectangular median apophysis of the male palp with the typically twisted distal processus (
,
). The male differs clearly from all the other species in the group by the shape of the embolus—long and thin, ending with needlelike unmodified tip (
,
) vs. ending with different modifications in
Z. thoni
(
),
Z. reticulatum
,
Z. rhodiense
,
Z. beroni
and
Z. imroz
or truncated in
Z. granulatum
(
). Also, the new species differs by the broad and rectangular distal extension of the median apophysis (
,
) vs. with narrower tip in all the other species.
Female unknown.
Distribution. Known only from the type locality in the Taurus Mountains (Namrun), Turkey .

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p:
In the diagnose of the
thoni
- group,
describes the embolus as being “semi-circular, linear, describing nearly half a circle, terminally widened into a small, specific knob”.
Zodarion granulatum
does not fully fit this diagnose. Although its embolus tip is also modified being truncated, it does not end in a knob. With the new species described here, it is clear that the
Z. thoni
- group contains also species with unmodified tip of the embolus and this should no longer be a diagnostic character for it. Despite that, the group remains consistent and is well characterized by the large, rectangular median apophysis with specifically twisted distal (prolateral) part as well as by the long, arch-shaped embolus. The females have narrow, coiled ducts of the vulva.

The present study does not resolve all the uncertainty in the taxonomy of the
Z. thoni
species-group. With the holotype of the
Z. thoni
lost, its identity remains unclear. Here Ifollow
and
who separate
Z. thoni
and ‘
Z. nigrifemur
’ (= Z. rhodiense sp. reval.), but in my opinion the difference between the two species is too small, and could be just variation. Such minor differences could depend even on the slight variations of the angle when taking photographs/drawings. The different descriptions of the males (
,
,
, and the one in the present paper) overlap significantly and it is difficult to extract reliable diagnostic features out of them. Moreover, no significant difference could be observed between the females.

Unfortunately, all the available material for this study was too old and not suitable for sequencing. Amolecular phylogeny of the group is urgently needed to properly delimit the species boundaries and distribution ranges.
